titleStmt.title: M50. Anon. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 9p. Paginated 1-9.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M50. Anon. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 9p. Paginated 1-9.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr> tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: 1 ANON.

"For many centuries afte (after) Britain became an island" the says "#"the untamed forest was king. Its moist and mossy floor was hidden from Heavens eye by a close drawn curtain woven of innumerable tree tops." On those matted boughs innumerable birds sang; but their song was only heard by a few skin clad hunters in the lcearings (clearings). Did the desire to sing come to one of those huntsmen because he heard the birds sing, and so rested his axe against the tree for a moment? But the tree had to be felled; and a hut made from its branches before the human voice sang too.
By a bank as I lay Musing myself alone, hey ho! A birdes voice Did me rejoice, Singing before the day And me thought in her lay She said, winter was past, hey ho!

The voice that broke the sielnce (silence) of the forests was the voice of . Some one heard the song and re embered (remembered) it for it was later wrteen (written) down, beautifully on parchment. Thus the singer had his audience, but the audience was so little interested in his name that he never thought to give it. For Tthe audience was itself the singer; Terly terlow" they sand; and "By, by lullay" filling in the pauses, helping out with a chorus. Every body shared in the emotion of Anons song, and supplied the story. Anon sang because spring has come; or winter is gone; because he loves; because he is hungry, or lustful; or merry. or because he adores some God. Anon is sometimes man; sometimes woman. He is the

common voice singing out of doors, He has no house. He l ves (lives) a r ming (roaming) life crossing the fields, mounting the hills, lying under the hawthown to listen to the nightigale (nightingale).

By shutting out a chimney or a factory we can still see what saw-- the bird haunted reed whispering fen, the down and the green scare never quite not yet healed along which he came when he made his journeys. He was a simple singer, lifting a song or a story from other peoples lips and lettig (letting) the audience join in the chorus. Somemimes (Sometimes) he made a few lines that exactly matched his emotion--
but there is no name mae (name) to that song.

Then when the houses had come together in some lcearing (clearing) in a ring and roads, often flooded, often deep in mud, led from hxxxx the cottage to the Manor, from the Manor to the Church in the middle, along the roads came minstersl (minstrels) came jugglers, bear leaders, singing their songs at the back door to the farm hands and the maid servants in the uncouth jargon of their native tongue.
Icham for woing al forwake Wery no water in wore

Up stairs they spoke French. Anons words were as uncouth to the master and mistress as to us. Anon singing at yhe (the) back door was despsied (despised). He had no name; he had no place, yet even if they felt contempt for the singer whose body took its [small?] part in the [dance?] man who made songs, they tolerated him. Even Kings and Queens

the scholar tell us, must have their misntre (minstrel). They must have They needed his comment, his buffoonery. his [uncouth?] at [illeg.] They kept him in the [illeg.] being, tolerting (tolerating) h m (him), as we tolerate those who say out loud what we feel but are too proud to admit. He used the outsiders privilege to co mock the solmen (solemn), to comment upon the established. The church men hxmxmxmxmxmxmxxx feared and hated hating the the anonymo s (anonymous) singer. They did their best to [illeg.] If they could, they pressed him and his [illeg.] actors gift into the service of the church. He was to be found acting the Mass in the church; but [illeg.] as he acted more and more his own art, he left the church, and staged his pageant in the churchyard, or later was given a pitch for his drama in the market place. Still he remained nameless, often ribald, often obscene.

Yet During the silent centruies (centuries) before the book was printed his was the only voice to be heard in England. Save for singing his song at yhe (the) back door the English might be a dumb race, a race of merchants, soldiers, preists (priests); who left behind them stones houses, cultivated fields and great churches, but no words. He it wasIt was he who gave voice to the old stories, who incidted the peasants when he came to the back door to put off their working clothes and deck them selves in green leaves. He it was who found words for them to sing, and shen (when) they went at the great seasons to do
himage (homage) to the old pagan Gods. He wxxxxxxxx taught them the songs the sung at Christmas and at midsummer. He led them to the haunted tree; to the well; to the old burial place where they did himage (homage) to the pagan gods. If we could see the village as it was before time

we should see tracks across the fields joing (joining) manor house to hovel, and hovel to church. Some of those paths of course were worn by soliders (soldiers) and labouerers (labourers). They must fight to
gether (gather) and plough together if they were not to be conquered by man and by nature. That connection isxx as time goes on and the [he? her?] me records the daily struggleclasses separate themselves, is still painfully recorded in old letter books and ledgers. It makes the staple of the old corresp ondence (correspondence) between the of and the and of . But there was also the the other less visible connection --the common belief. That track between the houses in the village has been grown over;- like the track along which the rode to .--no one rides that way now. But before time thxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx it was trod daily. which It led the peasants to the tree to the well. In spring it led to the Maypole, where they danced and sung Anons song. At Midsummer they lit the bon
fir (fire) on the hill. At Christmas the mummers acted the old Anons old play; and the boys came singing his wassailing song. The road led to the old graves, to the stones where in time past the English had done sacrifice. The peasnts (peasants), led by anon, still went that way by instinct, in spring and summer and winter. The old Gods lay hidden beneath the new. It was to them led by Anon that they did worship, in their coats of green leaves, bearing swords in their hands dancing through the houses, enacting their ancient parts.
It was the in 1477 that k finally was to kill Anon. but it was the press also that preserved him. When

p.sup: it brought to the surface the old hidden world

div.p: But, save that self consciousness had not hyet (yet) raised its mirror, the men and women are ourselves, seen

out of perspective, xxx elongated, foreshortened, but very old, with a knowledge of all good and
allevil (all evil). They are already corrupt in this fresh world. They have evil dreams. is doomed; the Queens are luftful (lustful). There never was, it seems, a time when men and women were without memory; were innocent There enver (never) was a young world. There Bbehind the English lay ages of toil and love. T is (This) That is the world beneath our consciousness; the anoymous (anonymous) world to whcich (which) we can still
re urn (return). Of the writer nothing is known. The scholar can find something. But Malory is not distinct from his book. The voice is still the voice of . murmuring [illeg.] about Kings and Queens who are base and heroic; vile and gentle, like ourslves (ourselves), stripped of the encumbrances that time has wrapped about us.

But printing press foreold (foretold) the end of that
anoyl s (anonymous) world; it is now written down; fixed; nothing will be added; even if the legend still murmurs on, and still down in the peants (peasants) rmember (remember) how " on the night of the full moon King Arthur and his men ride round the hill, and their horses are shod with silver." After that the audience became separate from the singer; After thatFor a time we we hxxxx find someone who looks back, who gathers together a chornicle (chronicle) of what has happened. We find the individual, emerging from the past; His name his ; he has a library; he owns a mastiff and digs up coins. is dead when we meet with him. The have gone their way. He sees the past against a back ground of the
presn t (present), and the present looks raw, degenerate against

p.sup: But The printed book brought into existence the man who can read the man who becomes conscious, of the present, of himself, against the background of the past. it brings into being the whole, the audience— a man like it.

div.p: against the past. There is too much comfort now; too many xmxmxx the pillow has taken the place of the old log with a dip in the middle; there are too many chimenys (chimneys). The young and are not the men their fathers were. They are tender and subject to rheumatism. Also they dress most fantasically (fantastically) com ared (compared) with theirancestors (their ancestors).

He does not see the mummers and the wassailers; he does not hear the voice of ; he scracely (scarcely) listens even to the song of Canterbury pilgrims. For The English past as saw it, served only to show up the material change--the change that had come over houses, furnt iture (furniture) clothing. There was no English literature to show up the
chnage (change) in the mind. the English songs were [illeg.] Anons song at the back door was as difficult cfor (for) him to spell as for us. But the old
Eglish (English) songs were more painful. for they reminded him of his lack of intellectual ancstry (ancestry). His intellectual pedigree only reached back to , to to . In order to have anscetors (ancestors) by way of the mind he must cross the his ancestors by way of the mind are the Greeks and Romans. His page is burdneed (burdened) with these proofs ofgood breeding--- ; ; , --he quotes them to prove his nobility of mind as we to prove ours quote the Elizabethans. The mummers and the wassailers, the actors who were actingwho staged their crude dramas in the churchayrd (churchyard) or in the market place hxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx were sxmxmx He turns from the present to the past; he ignores the acors (actors) who were acting their crude daramas (dramas) now in the market place. Yxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx

The histroians (historians) work from the outer to the inner; from the house they infer the tenant of the house. It is the house they uncover; the chairs, the tables, the bills, the close stolls (stools), the spinning wheels, the tapestry. It is as if we were bidden to infer from a tweed suit, six hats, a fox terrier, and a silver knovved (knobbed) walking stick the life and works of a novelist called . Save for Vhaucer (Chaucer) and Lydgate and the voice of Anon singing at the back door the English might be a dumb race; a race of merchants, s ldiers (soldiers), preists (priests) and builders who left nehind (behind) them stone houses, cultivated fields and many churches and cathedrals. ; but no words. The great house is silent. Only the furniture remains, stiff and ornate, fantastic and uncushioned.

At for instnace (instance) sat at her table rwiting (writing) to . Her lettres (letters) —compare them with might have
veen (been) sermons from the pulpi;t (pulpit); or state dosuments (documents), intrcaite (intricate)
inlvoved (involved) and evasive. She is a counsellor admonishing a sub ordinate; sShe (she) is awrae (aware) only of the wickedness fof (of) men, the dangers and decits (deceits) of the world; and the awfuless of God. Greek and Latin come to her pen as easily as nglish (English). If she has to descend to the actual object--a basket of strawberries--it is with cirumlocuitions (circumlocutions) and dark
insiutaions (insinuations). "I have sent them by the boy of my kitchen, a shrewd witted boy and prettily catchized (catechized) but yet an un toward rcrafty (crafty) boy...." She xxxxxx ex horts (exhorts): "God keep us sound in faith the faith and send us h lth (health) and a care to please God above all." She admonishes: "Be not speedy of speech, nor talk suddenly, but where
disctreion (discretion) requireth, and that soberly then...." Let not Lawson that fox, be acqainted (acquainted) with my letters...." So Lthe (the) , mother to the poet Earl writes:

Fear of God, fear of man, hate, agony, passion, surround them with the walls of a dungeon. There is no gaiety,
nu (no) freedom no familairity (familiarity) in the world the live in. Only in extremity, of hate, of fear, do urges them to pick up the pen The sound of the bible is in their ears, Itis (it is) a garment only to be worn when the mind is in the right attitude. And the garment may of course conceal a Lady Ann who is merry and gay; it may conceal a Duchess who is snesitove (sensitive), amorous and sensual; we cannot tell. Anybody may live on the other side of that wall of formal language. Using the prose of the Bible when they write prose the Elizabethans are unknown to us. They can say nothing simple, subtle, or little. Bright contrasted colours meet on ther (their) faces; carnation and snow; ebony and gold. In their portraits, the young mens bodies are sewn into padded doublets; school boys faces are raised above strached (starched) ruffs; and young women serve only to supp rt (support) heavy uilted (quilted) dresses stuck about with huge xxxx pearls.
